job_title: Assistant Director in Chestnut Hill, MA
pros: The benefits at BC are outstanding - after one year of working there, the administration chips in 8% of your gross, you add 2% and it goes into a TIAA or Fidelity retirement plan. There are unlimited sick days, 9-5 set hours with an hour off at lunch, lots of learning and professional development opportunities, 22 vacation days with the holiday break between Christmas and New Year's off as well, excellent medical and dental benefits, the list goes on. They really try hard to help employees maintain a good work-life balance as well and have all kinds of programs and services to accomplish that. The campus is beautiful, people are friendly and kind. It is certainly a fantastic place to work! They also pay well for higher education and typically have a 1-2+% cost of living increase each year. The administration is also working hard to diversify the workforce as well as fostering a culture of equity, justice and inclusion.
cons: Opportunities for getting new jobs internally seem limited for mid or late career folks. I think it's because so few people leave that higher level jobs don't become open all that often, but am not certain of that. It's been frustrating not being able to have a chance to get promoted into a role with more responsibility and higher pay. It's also difficult to afford housing within a reasonable commute - either renting or owning so that's an issue for sure.

review_title: Great benefits, not so great pay
job_title: Assistant Director in Boston, MA
pros: 8% employer contribution with 2% employee contribution to 401k. Unable to withdraw from 401k until of age or leave university. 22 days of vacation a year with the week between Christmas and New Year's off. 100% tuition remission for all classes taken at BC by the employee, employee spouse, and employee children. Tuition remission can be tax-free for employees if courses taken are related to the position. Job security is extremely high.
cons: Promotions and merit pay raises are discouraged by management and HR. Promotions only occur when higher positions become available, usually after a retirement. 2-2.5% university-wide annual raise with inflation. Pay is solely based on years of experience, not degree(s) held or contributions outside the job description. Prospective employees: Do not expect to be paid higher than the posted salary range. Positions will go unfilled for months, even years, due to prospective employees' counter-offers being too rich for university. Company culture is to stay in your lane and maintain the status quo. Jobs are very cyclical. Change only comes from the top.

review_title: Boston College UA is a Viper's Nest: AVOID
job_title: in Chestnut Hill, MA
pros: Depending on your role, you may get to travel. That's about it.
cons:
Leaders have created the worst working environment. One in particular micromanages everything and does not trust employees. As a result, everyone is walking on eggshells. His leadership style is that everything needs to be approved by him and as a result, employees have no autonomy over their work. 

It's extremely clique-y - those in fundraising OPENLY insult those in the Alumni Association as they "only care about events." It's done in meetings and in front of leadership.

I've seen employees berate one another - screaming - and nothing happens to them. Others question one thing and they are gone. There's a double standard in place. Some people have been there far too long - and disobeying requests from other departments - with no repercussions. 

The staff that are alumni cannot volunteer for BC. This clearly affects morale. 

No one knows how to communicate. The feedback process is a joke and HR does not support the staff - rather, they make sure BC's precious image isn't tarnished. 

BC is one of the lowest paying Advancement Offices. This is well-known in the industry.

There isn't a lot of movement - unless you are in fundraising. Then you get a promotion every year. It helps if you're young and attractive - there's a reason young female fundraisers have been hired.

job_title: Program and Events Specialist in Newton, MA
pros: Boston College has some of the most generous benefits - in terms of 401k, health plan, and tuition reimbursement. Every office has their mix of motivated and not-so-motivated individuals, but I can honestly say that I've met some of the very best co-workers at BC (including a couple mentors).
cons: Unfortunately, generous benefits means the base salary (I can only speak to staff and administration) is lower than you might find outside higher ed. And while BC innovates, it does so at a slower pace than corporate America, so if you're looking to make big change, be prepared to run into some red tape.

review_title: Not all it's hyped up to be...
job_title: Library Senior in Boston College, MA
pros: Benefits and time off are incentives.   Salary paid is good in comparison to similar jobs in other areas.  Some very good people to work alongside you, but not all is as good as it seems....
cons:
Con 1:  Management in the upper level appears clueless and ambivalent about what the reality of the workplace is.  They propose lofty goals from their lovely offices, but they lack the vision of what it looks like from the perspective of those serving the customer.  

Con 2:  Small but entrenched group of long-time staff who milk the system and lack professionalism.   They create a certain cliquishness that is very unwelcoming.   

Con 3:  Not really much room for advancement even if you have advanced degrees.

review_title: Dining hall is easy work, but annoying
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newton Center, MA
pros: Pretty easy work. They will work with you on hours meaning you can get as little or as much as you want and when you want without much hassle. My cons list is going to weigh more than my pros, but I swear it's not real bad stuff, just kind of annoying.
cons: the girl in charge of making schedules was the hardest part about getting the schedule I wanted. she was another student and never answered her emails. I emailed her for a month straight, and she wouldn't answer, but then expected us to answer her instantly. a manager yelled at me once for doing nothing when I always worked at and cleaned every station. just seems like lack of attention/care. but honestly it really was a good place to work. I also wasn't trained. they just through me in there. it was simple though. if you have half a brain, you'll catch on.

job_title: Administrative Related in Chestnut Hill, MA
pros: Benefits and salary are good.
cons: 1) Management is disconnected from the reality of the workplace.  They have lofty goals, but not very interested in hiring the staff to accomplish them.  Instead, they stretch the staff they have to the breaking point and it drives many to seek alternative employment.  2) Some long-time employees milk the system and do as little as possible.  This creates a lot of tension and frustration in the workplace for those burning the candle at both ends to get the job done. 3) No real room to move up

review_title: As long as you aren't a graduate student . . .
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Chestnut Hill, MA
pros: For the most part Boston College is full of caring individuals who make wonderful colleagues, particular those who work in non-academic administrative positions.
cons: As a graduate employee, it was hard not to feel slighted throughout my years at BC. I taught undergraduates for several years, as well as worked other part time jobs in offices that undertook initiatives which came directly out of the President's office. But there was little room for professional growth in these positions, and not a lot of incentive beyond wanting to pay the bills for another year.

review_title: Being a grad assistant and TA can be deeply meaningful and fulfilling work.
job_title: Graduate Assistant in Chestnut Hill, MA
pros:
* Flexible scheduling that fits your life as a grad student
* Wonderful opportunity to build professional relationships and mentor younger students
* Great opportunity to learn from professors and mentors
cons: You can't get paid multiple wage levels on campus, so my wage was set at the rate of a 2nd work study position which paid me less than I normally would have been paid as a graduate assistant.  University politics often impacted funding and the direction of innovated programs, making it hard to build something truly innovative to respond to current issues.

review_title: The BC MBA program is an extraordinary educational community that puts an absolute premium on excellence and values.
job_title: MBA Student in Boston, MA
pros: Anyone who is looking to leverage up their career, is open to new perspectives and people, wants to be an active member of a vibrant community, and believes that part of any companies bottom line is creating social value, will find themselves very happy in the BC MBA program.
cons: I think there's a temptation for MBA programs to compare themselves to Harvard. The reality is BC is not HBS the same way an apple is not an orange. Most people get that, but there is a small element of Harvard envy on campus.

job_title: Student Tech in Chestnut Hill, MA
pros: As a student, I work in the IT department at Boston College. The environment puts you right in the thick of things and forces you learn on the job. There is basic training in the beginning, but the vast majority of your knowledge will be gained from incoming customers. At the same time, management is not afraid to step in and help you through a difficult process. That said, the work office is generally relaxed unless it's packed with customers - which only happens once or twice a week.
cons: Customer influx is very inconsistent. Depending on your shift, there might be 3 or 30 people who walk in the door during your time there.

job_title: Front Desk Student Assistant in Boston College, MA
pros: An incredibly friendly office staff and I get to interact with International Students from all over world from all different backgrounds.In Additions i get to look into the world through other students coming to Boston College
cons: At first, with the first interactions with international students with different accents was a bit difficult for us to understand but as time went on and i got to hear all the different types of accents i became to become more accustomed to them

job_title: In the University Advancement Department in Chestnut Hill, MA
pros:
BC walks its talk; it treats employees extremely well, offering a wide range of benefits and perqs, excellent career development opportunities, good work-life balance, and generally treating its employees with respect. Very friendly atmosphere for people who might worry that they'd be out of place in a Catholic institution, such as GLBT folks, atheists, etc - you'll have no issues at BC. It truly lives its mission as an educator and an employer, and how often can you say that? I have never worked at any other company that I would even think of giving five stars to in the "culture and values" area, but BC deserves every one of them. 

Salary is low-average, which is usual at universities, but benefits are quite good, vacation time is fantastic, and tuition benefits plus the many, many, MANY other benefits available at an excellent university are unmatched. 

I joined BC during the recession, and it was truly astonishing to be in a place where they were expanding, doing construction, and spending money while the rest of the world got laid off. It's a school with tremendous potential and a clear vision and plan for realizing that potential. 

My advice to anyone considering a job at BC: leap on it. It's a great place to work.
cons: Extraordinarily hierarchical organization. It can be frustrating to try to get things done because heaven forbid we proceed without the approval of every single person on campus for every single initiative. And then let's double check just in case. It's possible that this is unique to my department, which is run by a lovely and very talented guy who's also a pathological micromanager - culture trickles down, so I can't say that this is pervasive across the institution, but it certainly is in the development department.

review_title: Great employer but political environment and not very innovative.
job_title: Associate Dean in Chestnut Hill, MA
pros: Very good benefits.  Great place to put yourself out to pasture.  Lots of holidays.  Early close on Fridays in Summer.  Week off between Christmas and New Years PLUS 22 vacation days.
cons: Way too many people out to pasture.  They come and they never leave.  Stale thinking.  Combined with growing popularity of the school it creates a dangerous arrogance.  They are protective of employees, which is great (didn't lay people off when Harvard and others were during economic crash).  But negotiate your salary hard when you're hired because it won't go up very fast.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Fantastic lab with a great atmosphere, the work is interesting but not too stressful. Learning a lot about the field which is good preparation for after graduation. Lots of autonomy...come and go on your own time, as long as you get your work done nobody will be breathing down your neck.
cons: A little disorganized at times, plus the university administration refuses to allow for graduate student unionization so they get screwed over sometimes with backpay among other things. This however is a university-wide thing and not specific to my lab. So the main issue is with the University administration, not with any faculty, graduate students, or PI's.

job_title: Communications Specialist in Chestnut Hill, MA
pros: Boston College provides a great working environment. They have a very beautiful campus, and the people I work with are very friendly. There is a strong concept of company culture; they value and promote loyalty. They provide excellent benefits.
cons: With the strong sense of loyalty, getting hired here is very difficult and a very long and arduous process. Although their benefits are great, you have to pay for silly things like parking on-campus, which can be as expense as $60/month. The college could use more diversity and sometimes can show preferential treatment towards hiring Alumni.

job_title: Resident Director in Boston, MA

Opportunities to get involved in projects outside your direct area, volunteer with international service trips, retreats, and other developmental opportunities.
cons: It can be difficult to progress in your career since people tend to stay in their positions for a long time. To move up you generally need to leave to another university then maybe come back years later. Compensation is in line with non-profit/education sector.

job_title: in New York, NY
